sections.title: Compounding: Quiet Growth, Big Impact
sections.content: Compounding is growth on top of growth. When your investments earn a return, those earnings get reinvested and begin earning too. The earlier you start, the more time you give compounding to work. Consistency beats perfection: a steady monthly contribution often outperforms sporadic, larger deposits.

points.title: Cash
points.description: Low risk, low return. Great for emergencies, not for long‑term growth.

points.title: Bonds
points.description: Loans to governments or companies. Typically steadier than stocks but lower expected return.

points.title: Stocks
points.description: Ownership slices of businesses. Higher volatility, higher long‑term return potential.

points.title: Funds
points.description: Bundles of many bonds or stocks (index funds/ETFs) that deliver instant diversification at low cost.

sections.title: Costs Matter
sections.content: Fees quietly erode compounding. Favor broad, low‑cost index funds. A 1% annual fee can cost six figures over a career.

sections.title: A Starter Portfolio Framework
sections.content: Pick an allocation based on time horizon and sleep‑at‑night test. Example: 80% global stock index + 20% total bond index for 10+ year goals. Automate monthly contributions. Rebalance once or twice a year to keep your risk level consistent.

sections.title: Get Moving This Week
steps: Open a brokerage or use an existing retirement account.
Choose one global stock index fund and one broad bond fund.
Automate a contribution you can sustain (even $50/mo).
Schedule a calendar reminder to rebalance every 6 months.

sections.title: Nervous About Volatility?
sections.content: Use a ‘glidepath’: start at a slightly more conservative mix and step up stock exposure every 6–12 months as your confidence grows.
